Reality - SIM cards are available at the international airports , buy them and get an IRCTC account to book trains, use OLA , Uber and metro trains instead of Auto rickshaw , Avoid sketchy neighbourhoods , like one would avoid faihill in philli .. importantly stay in hotels n hostels with at least 25 good reviews.. it's common sense travelling . And importantly eat at decent looking restaurants or the ones with good reviews n drink bottled water.. I had my laptop stolen in Valencia , purse in Barcelona , with people coming up to me trying get money while pretending to be helpful, there are crappy places everywhere but if you wanna go by paying bare minimum the experience won't be pleasant  neither a real reflection of the place.and that's true for everywhere ..

Actually regarding the "dirt" part in my opinion the answer is far more nuanced and complex than what many people think. During Indias Independece movement Inda was a very very poor country with only 12% literacy rate. The freedom movement was led by a small group of elite class including nehru and all.  Hence political unity was something which we never had as people. It was more like a collection of regions forming india. Now you wonder how is that related to garbage. Well, if people don't have a sense of patriotism or political identity as indian then it's quite natural they will not care about their surroundings. The south seems better because it has lesser population. But the sad reality is we as a nation especially the lower class(sometimes even the upper first) have not associated ourselves as indian first. We always see ourselves as tamil first or Malayali first. I know the word "nationalism" has a very negative connotation in the west especially Europe due to the two world wars but in a developing country like india which is so vast and so divided on language and religion a little bit of nationalism is needed for  political unity. I'm not trying to justify anything but this is my opinion on why we have this garbage problem and why it's so profound.

The truth about traveling to India 

India is the most awesome country to travel but there are some black spots that you should avoid.

if you say no to India, then you are doing injustice to kerla. 

u also had a wonderful time in mumbai.

1. Ladakh 
2. Sikkim 
3. Nagaland (and the other sister states) 
4. Kerla 
5. Andaman

The problem is when solo travellers, especially women travel to India. It is not an easy place to visit as most places on the sub continent are. Unfortunately we do not have the B&Bs as there are in the West, where a standard is laid down. In India standards are inspected by government clerks and many people who have them have no idea how to run them. I have met many single women and men travelling alone and we have enjoyed meeting others as well as my friends they are introduced to. Like me there are millions of Indians who have had similar experiences. Living in the UK for the last 20yrs, I showed this video to some of the Brits  here and they all felt that this She had this experience because she did not prepare of a solo trip herself. 

Travelling alone denies many of a chance of meeting genuine, hospitable and polite Indians or their family. They speak the same language as the visitors. Like any other countries, even in the educated West there are no go areas but on one's own how does one realise this. In fact our own women know where they can go alone. .
I feel sorry for women travellers, their safety is essentially dictated by how beautiful they are. The more attractive ones shouldn't even consider going to many parts of the world alone.

I'm sad to hear you had such a negative experience in India - I'm also a solo female traveler in India going on 4 months being here and have loved my time. It did take me awhile to get used to some of the hecticness though. Everyone has a different experience but here are two things other female travelers could possibly keep in mind to prevent this:

1) These problems are often way worse in Jaipur and other big tourist centers. But, this isn't representative of the rest of India. Go to Amritsar, Lucknow, Kolkata, and even Varanasi and some of these issues won't happen or at least not as frequently. I actually think having a guide and driver attracts most of this unwanted behavior (photos, scams, shouting, etc.) and when you're actually fully alone people tend to leave you alone more. If you're determined to go to someplace like Jaipur, I highly recommend going during the off-season for tourism (in the brutal summer heat) because it will be much calmer.

2) There's a difference between being unsafe and being uncomfortable. Based on this video, I don't think there was ever an actual danger risk, even though I totally get it was scary. In my experience, no one is violent or dangerous, they are just overworked, undertrained, and trying to bring money home to their families and you are the unfortunate recipient of the results of that. Even the hotel lock story seems like a classic case of undertrained staff in hotels but I doubt anything malicious was happening. Of course, just like every major city in the world, crime happens in Indian cities, and just because nothing bad has ever happened to me doesn't mean it can't happen. However, I think its important to know that many women do have positive experiences in India and discomfort does not equal danger.

Ladhakh - with beautiful Himalayan mountains

I'm from Shimla. If you and your friend come to India and want to do solo trip.
You either go really north of India (Jammu and Kashmir, Ladak, Himachal) or really south(Kerla) or north east 7 sisters state (Arunachal, Nagaland etc).
People in these places won't bother you or ask for pictures. People are nice here and you would feel comfortable there. Even Indian girls go to these states and have no issues even at night.
Other hindi speaking states are big no no... They have no population and you don't know what going to happen. Even I get culture shock when I get out of my town to hindi belt. People are loud, have no respect for others and have no idea of others consent.
Sorry to hear about your experience. It must have been difficult for you throughout the trip. Would recommend booking through reputed travel agent.

Actually those tea estate worker quarters must be close to 100 years old, build by colonial estate owners. Those are not plants on the roof, dirt sacks to prevents roofs from being blown away on which plants sprouted over time. Cow urine usage is increasing in India, particularly in rural areas, with a significant growth rate. Here are some key pointsÂ¹ Â²:
- *Annual Growth Rate*: The demand for cow urine products in India is rising at an annual growth rate of 12%.
- *Rural Consumption*: Over 50% of rural households consume cow urine regularly, driven by its perceived health benefits.

*Gujarat Consumption*: In Gujarat, around 6,000 liters of cow urine are consumed daily, with a significant demand for cow urine ark (condensed cow urine).
- *Product Varieties*: Cow urine products come in various forms, including flavored drinks (lemon, turmeric, and honey), body sprays, hand sanitizers, and floor cleaners.

The increasing demand is attributed to the perceived immunity-boosting properties and potential health benefits of cow urine, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic. However, it's essential to note that scientific evidence supporting these benefits is limited, and regulatory bodies have not approved cow urine for medical use.

I'm a very frequent train traveller. Extremely introverted in nature and having social anxiety. Whenever I travel, i avoid conversation with nearby people. I put on my headphones. I don't eat from ANYONE even if I'm very hungry, fearing there might be something mixed in the food and i might get robbed. I always book the upper berth cuz if i get lower, I'll have to deal with arguing with people who ask for exchange and i don't want to have that conversation. And in the upper berth, you don't have to deal with getting up and adjusting with middle berth guy for sitting- another conversation avoided.  I always stay on my upper berth and come down only when I've arrived at my station cuz i really don't want any conversation with anyone. Side upper is ideally the best but I'm too tall and my leg hurts having to bend it to fit myself there. 

But damn bro after watching this video I feel like I've missed out on so many experiences... You know what? Ima change. Let's see.

New hobby acquired: watch other people visit my native place! ğŸ˜‚

Your photography is some of the best I've seen of my home state! I lived in Munnar (pronounced MOON-AAR, by the way) the first 4 years of my life. My grandfather built the reservoir (and the dam/hydroelectric project) near there that you briefly showed! The diversity of India is something that most people in the West can't grasp... I sometimes ask them to imagine if Europe was one big country, it would be something like what India with our conglomeration of our states is like. Kerala is about as different from, say, Punjab, as Sweden is from Italy or Poland. It's also as different from its neighboring states as European countries are from theirs. More different actually -- almost every European language uses the same script. We have a different script for each language, and each state has a different language. I'm glad you were able to appreciate our diversity.

See, This is my message to all foreigners... I have been binge watching different people explore India and I just have like a ton to say... I wanna let my anger out, So just hear me...

Out of all states in India, Kerala is the cleanest... Has the most amount of english speaking people than any other state and is the the 1st state of India to gain 100% education... Literally anyone you meet will be school passed and not illiterate... And now, for the brown stereotype (brown munde)... Please don't think that everyone is brown or black, You know I myself am white, and i know tons of people who are too... Kerala is the best state in the whole entire India, and that's why it's called "God's own Country". 

Sorry, If I offended any fellow Indian... I just wanted to let my anger out, seeing all those stereotype from binge watching these things...

Many american, french, spanish or koreans come to India and make vlogs... but what they are unintentionally doing is going to places, where even us Indians won't go 'cause it's not safe... 
And You know what they will do? They will upload these videos in such manner that it makes our country look dirty... That everyone is POOR and isn't EDUCATED...
Why go to such places, and ruin our damn reputation when you can come to a state like Kerala, or Sikkim or any Eastern States as they are also so stunning and beautiful... and again just like Kerala , They are very clean...

STOP! stereotyping us and going to places where even we won't and then ruining our country's status... It's because of you guys, that India is thought to be poor... It's because of you guys, that hollywood has normalised stereotypical accents... Not everyone speaks like that you know! I myself and my family do have great accents that sounds like we are from america, but we are not!

What Allison said is True: "The only good thing americans think about India is the Taj Mahal"

I HOPE this helps people change their mindset, and i want YOU guys to help spread this message! Use #StopStereotypingIndia and spread this message to all damn social media platforms...

I wish you a GOOD DAY  <3

Diwali marks the return of Bhagwan Ram from exile after killing Ravan for his unrighteousness way of life involving touching(grabbing onto the hand) of a married woman therefore symbolizing victory of truth and righteousness over lies and unrighteousness way of life concomitantly it marks several other tales such as Mata Kaali's pooja and and Bhagwan Krishna defeating a rakchas named Narkasura; my point is it is more important for the people who celebrate especially the youth to take learnings from these festivals first then the sweets and bursting crackers because they light the way a good human being should walk on.
I hope you truly enjoyed the festival, certainly it can be rather heavy if its your first time especially when you're not used to the noise, but the moment with your loved ones engulfed in joy and happiness envelopes the noise and makes the moment remarkable, personally the pooja and rangolis and decorating the house are my favorite part as they help people bond not just families but everyone, would love to know how you felt about your experience.

PS; the poojas can get boring given the mantras are in Sanskrit a way around is understanding its meaning which in itself is a story and makes every pooja more interesting and easier to dedicate oneself to it that is if you wish. 

stay blessed, happy and may you all have a happy and prosperous life

I disagree that hitchhiking is all about luck. I've hitched all over the world for decades, and there are lots of things you can do when hitching to increase or decrease your chances of getting lifts. Main thing is don't hitch on fast roads, but find spots where cars are going slow enough to see you and react in time, and make sure there's a very easy and safe place cars can pull over for you. Look presentable enough, dont obscure your face with sunglasses etc, wear bright clothes if possible, make sure your backpack is visible so people know you're a backpacker. Don't just get in any car that stops, but ask where they're going and see if the place they're going will be a help or a hindrance to getting the next ride. Carry a physical detailed road map of the country/area you're in, as the map will have key information that Google Maps doesn't, such as petrol station locations. When doing the hitching itself, make sure your hitching arm and thumb are clearly outstretched, and not just resting down. A whiteboard, whiteboard markers, and rag can be very useful, even just as a prop. The more props you can display that indicate you're hitchhiking the better. Oustretched thumb, prominently visible backpack, readable sign with one or two words maximum. The sign isn't really necessary in a lot of situations but it can be a lifesaver sometimes. Some people say hitching should only be done during the day, but I've found that in some places, getting to a truck stop petrol station in the evening when trucks are doing longhaul trips can be useful if you just want to get where you're going and don't care about the scenery. Truckers will 99.99% never stop for you when they're moving, but the chances of one saying yes when you talk to them when they're parked or refuelling is very high. I could go on, but that's the basics I can think of

Hearing her story I remembered a poem by Kahlil Gibran :

And a woman who held a baby against her bosom said, Speak to us of Children.
     And he said:
     Your children are not your children.
     They are the sons and daughters of Lifeâ€™s longing for itself.
     They come through you but not from you,
     And though they are with you yet they belong not to you.

     You may give them your love but not your thoughts,
     For they have their own thoughts.
     You may house their bodies but not their souls,
     For their souls dwell in the house of tomorrow, which you cannot visit, not even in your dreams.
     You may strive to be like them, but seek not to make them like you.
     For life goes not backward nor tarries with yesterday.
     You are the bows from which your children as living arrows are sent forth.
     The archer sees the mark upon the path of the infinite, and He bends you with His might that His arrows may go swift and far.
     Let your bending in the archerâ€™s hand be for gladness;
     For even as He loves the arrow that flies, so He loves also the bow that is stable.

I genuinely, for the love of god, do not understand the mindset of foreigners in india. 

Trust me she's very excellent as a person, she's very energetic but i can't understand what she's trying to do in india. 

If she's on tour she hasn't even visited one single tourist spot. If she wants to try various food she hasn't even tried 1% of indian food. ( street food isn't really what you should eat very often as a foreigner. You're not used to it and might get sick)

Why would someone willingly want to go to some backwater local marketplace which is crowded as hell and genuinely too overwhelming for a foreigneer. Because people are not used to people looking like her and they will all gawk you in curiosity. Even as an indian i have going to crowded marketplaces so i go to malls. I just don't get it what she's trying to do. The whole video she just went around a super crowded market saying namaste to everyone. That's not really the best way to interact with locals if you want that. You could go to coffe shops and go to modern area you can talk to people who can actually communicate properly with you in silence.

Again, i really don't know what she's trying to do but this is a bad receipt for disaster what she's currently doing. She should not roam around at backwater market areas. Come on, you have such good money advantage as a foreigner! India isn't only crowded and rural! There is soo so much you can see and do but foreigners only want to be around slumy areas and then unfortunately something bad happens to them ( remember foreigners are more vulnerable for certain people to target, this is for any country)

Would you want to go in a area of USA known for having drug addicts and gunmen? Absolutely not. Same logic applies in india. Visit nature spots, historical spots, modern cities, villages ( if you're into that ). You're just wasting so much potential its painful to watch. 

Finally, I'm only saying all this because I'm concerned for you please don't take it in any wrong way.

Please visit Kailasa Temple at Ellora Caves in Maharashtra India. It's considered greatest architecture in history of mankind, because the way it was built seems unbelievable for even todayâ€™s time. The temple was built at least 1300 years ago. No stone or nothing was added they carved a mammoth Granite rock/mountain with intricate details. The Kailasa Temple is notable for its vertical excavation-carvers started at the top of the original rock and excavated downward. At least 400000 tonnes of stones have been removed in the process. About 7000 workers and their future generations worked for 135 years. One small mistake and you have to rebuild the whole temple because it's carved into the rock without adding anything, that too up to down. 
It has secret underground tunnels believed to be leading to underground city which is even more mysterious and government have totally locked that down and no researchers are allowed to go inside. 
other than Kailasa Temple there are 99 other cave temples there (100 total) of which 34 are open for public viewing. whole temple complex known at Ellora Caves.

This video is very touching and appreciated.  In 2006, at the age of 19, i travelled from my home in the Appalachian mountains (USA) to Uttarakhand and spent 1 month in the region.  I stayed in a tiny village called Lata that looked very similar to the Harsil valley.  It is somewhat close to Josimath, so a bit farther southeast along the mountain chain and adjacent to Nanda Devi National Park.  It was the first time I had been outside of my own country and I felt so incredibly welcomed and taken care of by the people of this region that it still blows my mind to this day. You did not even visit the world's biggest active Hindu temple in Delhi, the Akshardham temple(Angkor Vat being the world's biggest Hindu complex located in Cambodia is not a functional one conducting rituals, and has been desecrated and converted to an abandoned Buddhist temple, which has been furthered desecrated during communist rule).

Also, the Birla temple, Qutub Minar Complex(with Iron Pillar from 4th-5th century CE and remnants of the temples that were destroyed in the 1200s), Lotus Temple, Jantar Mantar, Agrasena ki baoli etc.
Some of them are new architecture, but most of them much older than what you visited!
Delhi was called Dhillika before the Islamic invasions which destroyed the city and its architecture, and a part of the city named Indraprastha was actually the capital of Pandavas from the Krishna-Mahabharata era.
So, yeah...you just scratched the surface and almost missed the whole of that ancient city's heritage, though your laid back approach and ready to be flexible attitude is a much needed one if someone wants to do travelling full time.

Please visit Kailasa Temple in Ellora Caves in Maharashtra India. It's considered greatest architecture in history of mankind, because the way it was built seems unbelievable for even todayâ€™s time. The temple was built at least 1300 years ago. No stone or nothing was added they carved a mammoth Granite rock/mountain with intricate details. The Kailasa Temple is notable for its vertical excavation-carvers started at the top of the original rock and excavated downward. At least 400000 tonnes of stones have been removed in the process. About 7000 workers and their future generations worked for 135 years. One small mistake and you have to rebuild the whole temple because it's carved into the rock without adding anything, that too up to down. 
It has secret underground tunnels believed to be leading to underground city which is even more mysterious and government have totally locked that down and no researchers are allowed to go inside.
